title: Bolton’s Departure Removes a Counterweight to Trump’s Foreign Policy
text:
The departure of John Bolton as White House national security adviser makes it more likely that President Trump will redouble his brand of personal diplomacy with Iran and other countries and world actors, international officials and foreign policy experts said Tuesday.

Mr. Bolton, who acted as a counterweight to many of Mr. Trump’s initiatives, including talks with the Afghan Taliban insurgent group, submitted his resignation Tuesday.

The departure of the hawkish Mr. Bolton was greeted positively by some Iranian officials. Iranian government spokesman Ali Rabiei applauded Mr. Bolton’s move in a conciliatory post on Twitter.

“Months ago, #JohnBolton had promised that #Iran would not be there in 3 months; we are still standing & he is gone,” he wrote. “With the ousting of its biggest proponent of war & economic terrorism, the White House will have fewer obstacles to understanding the realities of Iran.”

Suzanne Maloney, deputy director of the foreign policy program at the Brookings Institution, said the development significantly increased the odds of Mr. Trump meeting Iranian President Hassan Rouhani at the United Nations General Assembly gathering this month.

“Bolton’s departure may free @POTUS to engage more openly & creatively w/Iranian leaders, presumably they’re ready to make use of the opportunity,” Ms. Maloney wrote on Twitter. However, she added: “On its own, his removal won’t produce meaningful changes in Trump’s overall approach of maximum pressure.”

Before Mr. Bolton’s removal, analysts had expressed skepticism any such meeting would take place, saying the U.S. and Iranian negotiating positions were too entrenched to find common ground without losing face.

While Mr. Bolton’s exit opens the door to negotiations with Iran, it could worry important U.S. allies in the Middle East that are adversaries of Iran, including Persian Gulf nations and Israel, who believed that the Obama era of greater accommodation with Iran was over, said Danielle Pletka, of the American Enterprise Institute.

“The bottom line is it means uncertainty,” Ms. Pletka said. “Uncertainty in foreign policy, just like in economics, is not a good thing.”

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who made a public appearance at the White House shortly after Mr. Trump announced Mr. Bolton’s departure, played down the possibility that the president’s foreign policy might shift. “I don’t think any leader around the world should make any assumption because one of us departs that the president’s policy would change materially,” Mr. Pompeo said.

With the exit of Mr. Bolton, the Trump administration is losing one of its more experienced policy makers. Mr. Bolton’s deputy will fill the job until Mr. Trump appoints a new full-time adviser.

The vacancy at the National Security Council, which Mr. Bolton headed, occurs at the same time Mr. Trump is trying to find someone to lead the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, which has been vacant since Dan Coats resigned in July.

Similarly, the Department of Homeland Security, which oversees a range of U.S. security functions, is headed by an acting director following the resignation of Kirstjen Nielsen in April.

At the Defense Department, Secretary Mark Esper started work in his post after his Senate confirmation in July, months after the resignation of former Secretary Jim Mattis over differences with Mr. Trump.

Mr. Pompeo, a key Trump ally, has been in place since 2018, and before that was director of the Central Intelligence Agency. However, he has been mentioned as a possible candidate for the Senate from Kansas, and key lawmakers wouldn’t predict whether Mr. Bolton’s departure would have an effect on his calculations.

“I would guess on the Pompeo side of the equation is that his role in the administration, or his influence, becomes more important,” said Sen. Jerry Moran (R., Kan.). “If you’re looking for stability you wouldn’t want, in this case, another cabinet member to depart.”

—Alex Leary and Courtney McBride contributed to this article.
description: John Bolton’s departure as White House national security adviser makes it more likely President Trump will redouble his personal diplomacy with Iran and other countries and world actors, international officials and foreign policy experts said.
